Posts.Content: meima-Bev wrote: Hello everyone, I have  been reading your inspiring posts and have never seen any relating to my particular cancer.  I was originally diagnosed with breast cancer 17 years ago and thought I was a "survivor".  The cancer returned in my brachial plexus (which is the bundle of nerves near the underarm which control use of the arm and hand; this is the "inoperable" part as well as mets to femur, spine, ribs and sacrum.  I am doing surprising well.  No evidence of the tumer, just constant pain and limited use of arm and hand and bone mets are stable.  I am on Tamoxifen and monthly infusions of Zometa.  Tumor marker 27.29 is "15" Is there anyone else out there who has what I have or knows someone who has it.  I feel like I am alone in fighting this disease.  Thanks for letting me share.  Dx 8/31/2006, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2010 09:40AM meima-Bev wrote: Blondiex46, thanks for asking.  The tumor, which was originally 4.5mg in Aug. 06 was treated with 10 radiation doses, followed by continuous hormonals; Arimidex, Femara, they were working, but se's were unbearable then switched to Tamoxifen for the last three years.  Tumor shrinked by half after six months and completely disappeared after a year, and unbelievably has never come back.  I was originally seen in the hospital by a general surgeon, a plastic surgeon and a neurological surgeon; all agreed the tumor was inoperable (it was surrounding the bundle of nerves in the brachial plexus, which controls arm and hand movement).  Sorry for being so long winded; this is the first time I have ever told the whole story regarding this.  I thank God every day and don't take anything for granted.  I was left with nerve damage and limited use of my hand, but I'm not complaining, just grateful for the life I have. Posts.Content: meima-Bev wrote: I've been on once a month Zometa for approximately 2 3/4yrs. until this month.  I asked Onc. if we could go to every 6 wks. instead of 4.  I don't know why for sure I asked for change; maybe I thought I was doing so well, I could extend it. (I know, if it ain't broke, don't fix it).  I was fine until end of 5th. week then got SEVERE bone pain from hip, femor area (where I have rod), right down to my feet.  It was so bad, Onc. said go to ER for xrays.  She was worried about fracture.  Xrays were fine, but still unbearable pain.  Was told to rest, take pain med., ibuprophen,rest, etc..  This was all on Friday. I did as told and got some relief.  Monday I had my Zometa infusion, and by Tues. morning, no pain at all!  Can it be that it is so critical to stay on every 4 week schedule?? or is this just some crazy coincidence???  Meima Dx 8/31/2006, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: meima-Bev wrote: Ladies, I am at my wits end.  I have been on AI's continuously without a break for 6 yrs. (Arimidex, Femara, Tamoxifen, Aromasin).  I have very little quality of life.  I feel a bit guilty for complaining since the cancer is still in my bones; very extensive, but no organ involvement yet. I rarely leave the house since I can't take a walk, or stand in one place for more than a couple of minutes. (My husband will take me out in the wheelchair if I really want to get to get out).  The pain, numbness, buzzing pain is continuous and worse at night, so sleeping is sporatic.  I have tried nsaids with minimal success.  Pain meds made me sick and constipated.  Currently trying Tramadol and switching back to Vicodan.  Not much help.  I am seriously considering asking my Onc. to put me on Chemo. (I was on CMF at original bc diagnosis, and it was actually easier to tolerate than the AI's., although it was only for 6 mos. and not long term like this "easier" treatment).  I am not a complainer, but I am so lost right now, any advice would be welcome. Sorry for the long post, and thanks for listening.    Bev Dx 8/31/2006, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 12:56PM meima-Bev wrote: Hi Tamara:  I have been on Tamoxifen for a while now.  Will be three years in August.  Before that I was on Arimidex and Femara, respectively,  for a year.  Although these hormals are considered a "milder" treatmet, they are not without side effects, however in many cases they really work for us  er+ gals.  Bone pain, numbness, insomnia, night sweats, depression, etc. are just some of the side effects.  I still find myself crying sometimes for no apparent reason, but very infrequently now,  and I always feel better after a good cry  Please take heart, you are perfectly normal.  Just think of the the big job that little white pill is doing. Feel free to PM me if there's anything I can do.  My best wishes to you.    Meima
